title: Russell Watson's sadness at the loss of his grandad at just 50 because of alcoholism

When I got ill with the brain tumours it changed everything.

Of course, if someone had said to me, ‘Do you fancy a great big lump in your head that’s going to haemorrhage and you might die?’

I’d have said, ‘No thank you.’

But looking back on it from where I am now, I think if that hadn’t happened, my viewpoint on life – and everything – would probably be very different.

There’s no time for negativity now, it just infuriates me.

Life can sometimes bring you down, but I do try to avoid negative people.

I just want happy, friendly, jokey people in my life. Not miserable sods.

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

(Image: RUSSELL WATSON COLLECT.)

The most important thing in the world to me suddenly wasn’t success and sustaining it.

I’d have people on the phone saying, ‘Got an interview for you on Saturday and you need to do it.’

I’d say, ‘But it’s my only day off this week.’

‘I know, but it’s really important.’

There was one year, around 2002, it was so intense that I slept in my own bed twice that year.

Now I just say, ‘P*ss off, I’m having a day off and spending some time with my family and that’s it.’

Gary Barlow was on the same working men’s club circuit as me back in the day.

About 10 years ago we were chatting and he said, ‘I wouldn’t have missed that for the world, because it gives you an apprenticeship, you learn how to communicate with an audience.

If something goes wrong you learn how to deal with it on the spot.’

And it’s true.

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

(Image: Getty)

My grandad was a fantastic piano player and was coached to the highest level, but he was too nervous and shy to get on stage.

I remember as a kid there was a massive Steinway piano in his front lounge, which basically dominated the whole area.

When he used to play all the Chopin waltzes, I’d just go in there and sit and lean against the piano leg for hours just listening to him play.

I couldn’t move.

I wasn’t interested in playing with Action Men or anything.

I’d just go in, sit, feel the vibrations down my back and just listen to him playing.

I loved every minute of it.

Through his insecurities my grandad became an alcoholic, and that’s what killed him in the end.

He died in his 50s, sadly.

I think he’d have been mega proud of me.

Attaining success is relatively easy, sustaining it is bloody hard work.

I think in the early days I was selling more records than most of the high-profile pop artists.

I was one of the biggest-selling male artists in the UK, the first ever million seller as a classical artist, I don’t think anyone’s done it since.

I was on the crest of a wave, so you start walking with a bit more of a swagger.

Well, it only lasts for so long and every peak has its trough.

I did a gig at the Vatican and it was amazing.

I remember how they pitched it – ‘a private concert for Pope John Paul II

There’s 3,500 people in the audience, all specially invited dignitaries and royalty from across Europe.

In the front row you’ve got 50 red-robed cardinals, you’ve got the Pope in his own little private box area, I had a 140-piece orchestra, 500 choral singers and supposedly 500 million people watching it live on television.

I remember thinking, ‘Blimey, if this is private, I wonder what a public one’s like!’

My secret snapshot

You know what a Shih Tzu is?

A zoo with no animals!

No, the Shih Tzu is called Muffin, the Saluki on the right is Poppy and the black greyhound is Blaize, they’re rescues.

The greyhound adores my missus and the Shih Tzu never leaves my side.

When I go into the hall to sing, to do my vocal scales, Muffin comes in and starts howling next to me – I don’t know whether that’s a good thing!

I’ll be going, “La la la la la la la la,” and the dog will be like, “Aroooo!” next to me.

Sounds better than some of the sopranos I’ve worked with…

Blaize was on a photoshoot I was doing a few years ago.

We were over-running at the end of the day and my assistant goes, “He needs to get back, the dogs’ home shuts at half past five.”

I looked down at the dog, the dog looks up at me and I’m like, “Sh*t, he’s coming home with us,” and he’s been with us ever since.

Poppy was thrown out of the back of a van at 70 miles an hour, wrapped in a blanket.

She was in a pool of blood, with all her legs broken at the side of the motorway. So we took her on from the rescue centre

I can go away for two weeks and sometimes I’m looking forward to seeing the dogs more than the missus!

I can get in at 2am and the wife’s upstairs snoring , but the dogs are stood by the door like, “Ey up, where have you been?”

I’ll get upstairs and my missus will say, “Turn the light off, it’s too bright!” I’ll be like, “Cheers!”

Russell Watson and Aled Jones release their second album, Back In Harmony on 1st November
description: The classical music star on what his brain tumour taught him about life and fame and his love for his Shih Tzu and Saluki dogs
